results.title: Wall Street
results.creator_credit: Oliver Stone, Edward Pressman and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Skinny neckties and double-breasted suits adorn Wall Street, which follows the path of Bud Fox (Charlie Sheen) into a milieu of corporate capitalism. He soon realises to stay in this new world with high-powered corporate espionage player Gordon Gekko (Michael Douglas) he must break a few rules. Gekko represents one of three father figures for Fox, the other two being his real father and his boss at the broking firm, all of whom give him constant advice. However, Fox’s overwhelming desire for gold cufflinks and brick-like cellular phones steer him down the path of corruption and greed and he soon realises the price of the pursuit of overnight success. Director Oliver Stone captures the hectic hum of the commerce world and encapsulates the greed that is synonymous with the rise of capitalism in the 1980s. Michael Douglas received an Oscar for Best Actor at the 1987 Academy Awards for his role as Gekko.

results.title: When Brendan met Trudy
results.creator_credit: Kieron Walsh, Lynda Myles, BBC Film Unit, Collins Avenue and Dendy Films
results.brief_description: Roddy Doyle (The Van, The Snapper, The Commitments) wrote the screenplay for this romantic comedy, set in modern day Dublin. Brendan is a shy schoolteacher, with few friends and no sex life to speak of who is obsessed with old films. He imagines himself at the centre of all his favourite roles, from “The Quiet man” to Godard’s “Breathless”. One evening whilst drinking in a local pub Brendan meets Trudy - an outgoing, vivacious and bubbly blonde - his complete opposite. Despite a disastrous first date Brendan and Trudy form an unlikely romance. Trudy’s secretive nature about her line of work leads Brendan to believe she is some kind of criminal, perhaps even a violent one. Brendan’s attempts to introduce Trudy to his snobbish family are disastrous and the pair struggle to keep their romance aflame. Characters enact scenes from Brendan’s favourite films, replete with subtitles. Part of the appeal of this film is the litany of film references and clips lifted from old movie classics. Directed by Kieron J. Walsh and starring Flora Montgomery and Peter McDonald.

results.title: The Shootist [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Don Siegel, William Self, M Frankovich and De Laurentiis Entertainment Group
results.brief_description: Set in 1901, John Wayne plays John Bernard Books - an ornery, aging gunfighter who returns to his old hometown, where his presence is unwanted and his way of life deemed obsolete. Informed that he has terminal cancer in advanced stages, Books determines to die quietly and with dignity, but several enemies decide to settle old scores before Books passes on. Boarding with a widow and his son, both of who form an attachment to him, Books tries to deter the hero-worshipping son from adopting his dangerous way of life. The film’s story serves as a parallel to Wayne’s own stellar career as a hero of the Western genre (and Wayne had cancer whilst shooting his final film). In this revisionist Western, Siegel frames the narrative within a series of identifiable dichotomies of the old/new West, horse power/machine engines, buggy/automobile and 19th/20th century mores. Also stars Jimmy Stewart as Books’ aging doctor and Lauren Bacall. Original music by Elmer Bernstein.

results.title: Ulysses' gaze [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Theo Angelopoulos, Eric Heumann, Georgio Silvagni, Paradis Films, Mega Channel and Greek Film Centre
results.brief_description: Harvey Keitel is a Greek filmmaker who returns home after thirty-five years in America. He is in search of a lost film directed by the Manakias brothers, a film he believes to be the original “first film ever made”. His journey takes him on a journey through the Balkans, from Greece to Albania, from Bulgaria to Romania, a journey that ends in the besieged city of Sarajevo. On its release, “Ulysses Gaze” was criticised for its supposed ambivalent stance on the civil war in the former Yugoslavia. In hindsight, however, the film is an elegant and haunting eulogy on the death of utopia, and a film which acknowledges a much more complicated history to the Balkans than the one presented in the simplistic and moralistic films emerging from Western Europe. Ambitious and complex, “Ulysse’s Gaze” is also finally moving and heartbreaking; in its retelling of The Odyssey it passionately illuminates all that has been lost in the mad rush to replace culture with consumerism, to replace identity rooted in history with the fiction of perpetual recreation in cyberspace. There are scenes in this movie - the dismantling of Lenin’s statue, the final serenade in the Sarajevo fog - that confirm Angelopoulos as one of the leading film directors in the world today. Cast includes Erland Josephson, Maia Morgenstern and Thanassis Vengos.

results.title: The Bad and the beautiful
results.creator_credit: Vincente Minnelli, John Houseman and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: The Bad and the beautiful casts a sharp eye on the studio system of Hollywood and its machinations. Legendary (mythical) Hollywood producer Jonathan Shields (Kirk Douglas) is a ruthless, amoral player in the film game, who has a slew of great films to his credit and a chorus of detractors to match. Shields’ rise to fame and power is told from three perspectives - the actress, the director and the writer. Each provides the audience with extensive flashback sequences that regale a story of their dealings with Shields. In each case Shields manipulated the individual for his own ends, to the detriment of his personal relationships. Douglas plays Shields as a charming authoritarian patriarch whose humanitarian misdeeds are to be forgiven in the name of art. Purportedly based on Darryl F. Zanuck (a key Hollywood player in the 1950s and 1960s), Shields could indeed reflect any number of megalomaniac studio heads. Directed by Vincenti Minelli, the film is a lush melodrama, typical of the MGM style of the 1950s and won numerous awards including five Oscars. Also starring: Lana Tuner, Walter Pidgeon, Dick Powell, Barry Sullivan and Gloria Grahame.

results.title: Claire of the moon
results.creator_credit: Nicole Conn, Pam Kuri and Demi-Monde Productions
results.brief_description: Two successful writers—a promiscuous heterosexual novelist and a brooding lesbian sex therapist—are assigned a cabin together on a writer’s retreat for women. The two women are total opposites and argue constantly about their different philosophical and sexual orientations. Yet underlying their animosity is a growing sexual tension which, after much angst and rhetoric is finally consummated. Overly earnest in its intellectual attempts to explore female sexuality, “Claire of the moon” fails to engage the viewer on an emotional level. The long-awaited ‘climatic’ sex scene at the film’s conclusion only partially makes up for the tiresome talk-fest that precedes it. Cast includes Trisha Todd and Karen Trumbo.

results.title: Longtime companion
results.creator_credit: Norman Rene, Stan Wlodkowski and Samuel Goldwyn Company
results.brief_description: One of the first American films to deal with the AIDS epidemic, Norman Rene’s ‘Longtime companion’ traces the lives of a group of young American gay men living and dying in the time of AIDS. The film’s starting point is 1980 when the disease is first mentioned in the New York Times. Initially referred to back then as ‘Gay-Related-Immune-Disorder’, the early whispers of a mysterious ‘gay cancer’ hardly rated a mention. Based on a Craig Lucas play, the film documents the rapid spread of the disease throughout the eighties as these once healthy men are suddenly faced with their own mortality. The film and play takes its title from the refusal of the New York Times to acknowledge homosexual partners in their obituary column, preferring the more discreet term ‘longtime companion’. At the time of the film’s release it was criticized for being too discreet in its attempt at dealing with homosexuality and AIDS, and was conservative enough for cast member Bruce Davison to win the most mainstream of accolades, a Best Supporting Actor at the Oscars. The film’s sentimental finale drew the most fire, particularly from a very politicized Queer movement, who saw it as innocuous and conservative (three years later Jonathan Demme’s ‘Philadelphia’ would also draw the same criticism). In retrospect however the film’s tenderness for it’s characters and it’s earnest attempt to chronicle the devastating effect of the epidemic ultimately accumulates an emotional resonance that moves, even in it’s final wish-fulfillment coda. Cast includes: Campbell Scott, Dermot Mulroney, Michael Schoeffling, Mary Louise Parker.

results.title: The Gay deceivers
results.creator_credit: Bruce Kessler, Joe Solomon and Fanfare Film Productions
results.brief_description: Late sixties comedy about two young heterosexual men who pretend to be a gay couple in order to dodge the draft. Although the Army rejects the two, the recruiting officer questions their story and they are forced to move together into an all-gay L.A. apartment complex to add weight to their lie. Humour revolves around the comedy of misunderstandings that ensue involving the stereotypically ‘campy’ residents of the apartment complex. Though based on a homophobic premise, and aimed at a straight audience, the film is of interest as a naive camp curiosity and contains a few genuinely funny moments (and many unintentional ones). Along with “Boys in the Band” this was one of the only American 1960s mainstream films to feature homosexual characters. Cast includes Kevin Coughlin and Larry Casey.

results.title: Lust in the dust
results.creator_credit: Paul Bartel, Tab Hunter, Alan Glaser, New World Pictures and Fox Run Productions
results.brief_description: This camp, affectionate spoof of B western films, features drag-queen and cult-movie star Divine (1945-1988) best known for her performances in the films of John Waters. Basically a series of comedy skits that draw heavily on stereotypes of the western genre, the plot revolves around a group of mis-assorted characters that converge on the frontier town of Chile Verde in search of buried gold. Soon the town is turned upside down as lust, greed, and passion are driven to a fever pitch. Divine plays Rosie Velez, a voluptuous barmaid who encounters Clint Eastwood-esque gunfighter, Abel Wood (played by veteran actor Tab Hunter) in the desert. The performances of the cast of seasoned comic actors make up for the shortcomings of the script in this silly but fun, raunchy romp through a very wild Old West. Cast also includes Geoffrey Lewis, Laine Kazan, Cesar Romero and Henry Silva.

results.title: La Cage aux Folles 3: the wedding
results.creator_credit: Georges Lautner, Marcello Danon, Da Ma Produzione and Columbia Films
results.brief_description: Third and final installment of the “La Cage aux Folles” comedies begins with the St. Tropez nightclub of the title in serious financial trouble. When club owner Renato learns that his lover and the club’s star drag artiste Albin, is about to inherit a vast fortune from a distant relative, he thinks his problems are solved. But the gay couple’s long running relationship is thrown into chaos when they find out there are strings attached. Albin must marry and produce a heir within eighteen months or the whole inheritance will be forfeited. Despite consultations with marriage brokers and all the best intentions, it seems nothing will assist Albin reach his reward - until help arrives in an unlikely form. Cast includes Ugo Tognazzi, Marcel Bozzuffi, Michel Galabru and Antonella Interlenghi. In French with English subtitles.
